tossups.question: Today, this adjective usually denotes the musical lines which Christoph Bernhard described as passus duriusculus. This adjective names a piece whose "Recitative" ("reh-sih-tuh-TEEV") section ends with a pedal point on D accompanying descending diminished seventh chords, and which begins with two rapid ascents and descents of a D minor scale in triplet 32nd notes. The five-voice madrigal "Moro, lasso, al mio duolo" exemplifies "direct" methods of introducing a musical quality denoted by this adjective, used by (*) Carlo Gesualdo. It names a D minor keyboard piece by J. S. Bach which pairs a fantasia and fugue. By definition, Arnold Schoenberg's serialist pieces make use of the entirety of a scale denoted by this adjective, whose notes are encompassed by the circle of fifths and include all twelve tones. For 10 points, name this adjective which suggests color in music.
tossups.answer: chromatic [or chromaticism; accept Chromatic Fantasia and Fugue]

tossups.question: Scholar Karl Kerenyi connects a set of rituals centered on this substance to a constellation representing a machine owned by the Egyptian god Shezmu. An instrument called the "bullroarer" accompanied rituals centered on this substance which originated in the Zagros Mountains. Groups of people carrying this substance, called thiasoi ("thee-AH-soy"), were identified with the retinue that accompanied a god back from India. Diodorus Siculus writes that production of this (*) entheogen ("en-THEE-oh-jen") was identified with the dismemberment and rebirth of Zagreus, as re-enacted in rituals in which it was stored in a krater ("KRAH-ter") and placed in a bull's horn. The daughters of Cadmus consumed this substance and murdered Pentheus in their role as maenads ("MAY-nads"). For 10 points, name this liquid which was consumed during bacchanals ("BAH-kuh-nawls").
tossups.answer: wine [or oinos; or methu; prompt on alcohol or booze; prompt on grapes or grapevines] (The constellation is Shezmu's wine press.)

tossups.question: In a story by this author, a lonely woman points to a "big nail to the right of the front door," which once held the cage of a precious bird she bought from a Chinese man. In another story by this author, a cry of "Roo-coo-coo-coo" prompts Reggie to wonder if he and Anne could be like the two title birds. In a third story by this author, a couple on a park bench insults the furs worn by the title English teacher. Ironically, this author's story "The Canary," but not her story (*) "Mr. and Mrs. Dove," is part of her collection The Dove's Nest. A basket of baked goods is brought to the dead man Scott's house in this author's best-known story, which ends with the line "Isn't life-" For 10 points, what author of "Miss Brill" wrote about Laura Sheridan planning a celebration in "The Garden Party"?

Description acceptable. Public APIs developed by the company Diffbot use computer vision algorithms to perform this process. This process can be performed by using the library Guzzle to receive and parse DOM trees. In March 2020, LinkedIn petitioned the Supreme Court to hear a case related to the legality of the use of this process on its site by hiQ. The library (*) BeautifulSoup is commonly used for this process in Python. Programs that perform both indexing and this process can have their action regulated by a robots.txt file. Using this process to gather email addresses is prohibited in Australia. Bots and web crawlers can perform, for 10 points, what process, the automated gathering of text and data from webpages?
tossups.answer: web scraping [or data scraping; accept descriptive answers that indicate data/text is being extracted or harvested or collected from a webpage; prompt on web crawling before mention; prompt on answers which refer to parsing websites or HTML parsing; do not accept or prompt on "data mining" or "web indexing"]

tossups.question: A treasonous scribe enticed two pages to assassinate this ruler out of anger at his (emphasize) adoption of the custom of making subjects kneel and kiss his feet, called proskynesis. This ruler ordered drinking cups and draperies to be burnt in honor of the gymnosophist Calanus. Up to 20,000 talents were distributed to pay debts during an event in which this ruler married off many of his generals to foreign wives at (*) Susa. This ruler traveled to the Temple of Zeus-Ammon in Siwa in order to prove the divinity of his father, as recounted in the Anabasis written about his life by the Nicomedian historian Arrian. Later in life, this ruler married the princess Roxana after conquering Bactria. For 10 points, name this Greek ruler who adopted many foreign customs after conquering Persia for Macedon.
tossups.answer: Alexander the Great [or Alexander III of Macedon, or Alexandros III of Macedon, or Megas Alexandros]

tossups.question: An artist sits cross-legged working on a painting of one of these events in a sculpture by Samuel Aloysius Murray. To restore a painting of one of these events in 1961, Theodor Siegl's team removed varnish that had yellowed. A self-portrait of the artist lies behind Mary Clymer in a painting depicting one of these events, in which the title figure stands at left in white overseeing the central scene, contrasting with the bored-looking men in black (*) suits in the background. A painting that was rejected by the 1876 Centennial Exhibition in Philadelphia depicts a woman in black looking away in horror from one of these events while students take notes. For 10 points, David Agnew and Samuel Gross were painted performing what action in two paintings by Thomas Eakins ("AY-kins") of their respective clinics?
tossups.answer: surgery [or operations; accept anatomy lessons; accept specific kinds of surgeries; prompt on medical school lessons or medical school classes; prompt on clinics before "clinics"]

tossups.question: An ethnicity in this mountain range that claims descent from Alexander the Great was historically differentiated with another ethnicity by their practice of wearing black and not red robes. Another ethnicity living in this range possibly received its name from the fact that it descended from 1,000 of Genghis Khan's soldiers. In contrast to the Kalash people of this range, Islam is practiced among those who live in its province of (*) Nuristan ("noor-is-stahn"). Ancient peoples in a valley surrounded by this range constructed the now-lost Buddhas of Bamiyan. The Hazara ("huh-zah-ruh") people, who live in the western portions of this range, speak a dialect of Persian closely related to Dari. The Khyber Pass runs through, for 10 points, what mountain range, which straddles the border between Afghanistan and Pakistan?

Mono Jim was killed while engaging escaped convicts from this state in 1871, giving a neighboring state's Convict Lake its name. This state's Territorial Enterprise newspaper published a fictional account involving a man who scalped his wife in Empire City. Abraham Curry, considered to be the founder of this state's capital, ran a branch of the U.S. Mint in it. In this present-day state, the Grosh Brothers discovered a (*) mining site that was later supplied by the Virginia and Truckee Railroad. A city in this state that was founded on the site of the Mormon Fort Baker would later be home to the gangster Bugsy Siegel. Mark Twain was one of the earliest to seek riches by mining silver from this state's Comstock Lode. For 10 points, what state's capital was eventually named after the frontiersman Kit Carson?

Part of this collection opens with a poem that speaks of "revolving cycles in their wide sweep having brought me again" and is set in "the garden the world anew ascending". That sequence in this collection ends with a line declaring "Be not afraid," from a poem comparing the speaker to a man as "early in the morning". A man and woman sold at auction in a "slave-mart" are described in the seventh and eighth parts of yet another of its poems, whose ninth section lists (*) "skin, the sunburnt shade, freckles, hair" before concluding "O I say now these are the soul!" The speaker declares "the armies of those I love engirth me and I engirth them" in a poem from this collection's "Children of Adam" sequence titled "I Sing the Body Electric". For 10 points, name this magnum opus of Walt Whitman.

At around 100 gigapascals, this element transitions to a superconducting zeta phase. Neil Bartlett got the idea to react xenon with platinum hexafluoride after discovering that the latter can oxidize this element. At high pressure, this element transitions to a phase made of eight-atom rhomboid clusters, which is dark red. A molecule of this element can react with elastomers, such as rubber, to cause (*) cracking. The presence of unpaired electrons in the two pi-star orbitals explains why the most common allotrope of this element is paramagnetic. Cells use a dismutase enzyme to get rid of harmful free radicals of this element. Robert Goddard used a mixture of gasoline and this element to produce the first liquid-fueled rocket. For 10 points, name this element whose allotropes include ozone.

In 1946, students in this city engaged in "anti-American violence" after U.S. Marine William Pierson kidnapped a girl from here. Szeto Wah ("zeh-toe wuh") helped organize Operation Yellow Bird to help protesters in this city flee their country. In three days, students at this city's Central Academy of Fine Arts constructed a Styrofoam statue inspired by Vera Mukhin's Worker and Kolkhoz Woman. Students in this city drafted a 1919 manifesto opposing the Treaty of Versailles, sparking the (*) May 4th movement. Wei Jingsheng ("way jing-shung") compared democracy to the "fifth modernization" in a big-character poster posted to this city's Democracy Wall. Jeff Widener took a photograph in this city that depicts a man blocking the path of four tanks. For 10 points, name this city where the Chinese government quelled pro-reform protests in Tiananmen Square.

A mutualistic member of this genus that lives in the colon metabolizes tryptophan into the only bioavailable 3-indolepropionic acid. It's not E. coli, but one member of this genus is the most common cause of emphysematous cholecystitis and gas gangrene. Another organism in this genus secretes a zinc metalloprotease that cleaves SNAP-25, a SNARE protein that mediates vesicle fusion. Another member of this genus opportunistically infects the (*) colon of some patients taking broad-spectrum antibiotics. Yet another member of this obligately anaerobic genus produces heat-resistant bottle-shaped endospores that can contaminate improperly prepared canned foods, causing flaccid paralysis in affected individuals. For 10 points, what bacterial genus includes the causative agents of tetanus and botulism?
tossups.answer: Clostridium [accept Clostroides due to ambiguity over the classification of C. difficile; accept Clostridium sporogenes or Clostridium perfringens or Clostridium difficile or Clostridium tetani or Clostridium botulinum]

tossups.question: In a fable, a fisherman stumbles upon a utopia named for these objects which is isolated from the world's politics, but is unable to show its location to his village. In a novel, a character shrinks himself to two inches tall after taking some of these objects, after which he is awoken by seven fairies, who gather these objects for a feast thrown every 6,000 years by their queen. In another novel, a place that produces these objects is where the line "we merely hope to die on the (*) same day, in the same month and in the same year" is delivered. Xi Wangmu's ("shee wong-moo'z") palace contains a place guarded by Sun Wukong where some of these objects "of immortality" are grown. A promise to protect the Han Dynasty is made by Zhang Fei, Guan Yu, and Liu Bei in an orchard of, for 10 points, what fruits?
tossups.answer: peaches [accept peach blossoms, or peach trees, or peaches of immortality, or Peach Garden Oath, or xiāntáo, or Táoyuán Sān Jiéyì]

tossups.question: After this country botched a gradual switch to the Gregorian calendar, it returned to the Julian calendar by adding an extra leap day to 1712, which thus had a 30-day February. A king of this country ran a twin study to show that coffee was harmful; later, after taunting would-be assassins in an open opera box, that king was assassinated at a masked ball. The nobleman Johann Patkul ("PAHT-kool") helped forge a (*) secret alliance against this country, where the Hats and Caps factions dominated a brief parliamentarian era called the Age of Liberty. Augustus the Strong was part of an alliance against a young king of this country who fled to the Ottoman Empire after losing the Battle of Poltava. For 10 points, name this country whose Vasa dynasty kings included Charles XII, who lost the Great Northern War.

This researcher notes that 82% of surveyed subjects said they were "glad" to have participated in one experiment in response to an ethical critique from Diana Baumrind. This researcher solicited 12-year "shadowers" to speak words given by professors in an earpiece to test his theory about people who speak thoughts which aren't from their own body, as in an Edmond Rostand play. In another experiment, he sent students to ask "May I have your seat?" on (*) subway trains. This theorizer of "cyranoids and the "familiar stranger" tasked Omaha and Wichita residents with mailing a packet to a person in Massachusetts via only close friends and relatives in the "small world" experiment. For 10 points, what Yale social psychologist studied obedience by instructing people to deliver electric shocks?

Marie Menken dedicated a 1961 experimental short film shot in this complex to Kenneth Anger. A poem inscribed on a fountain in this complex compares its water to "the lover who in vain / tries to hide his tears from his beloved". This complex’s decorations uniquely use all seventeen wallpaper groups, whose tessellations greatly inspired M.C. Escher. This complex, which is named after the (*) red clay used to build it, contains a rectangular pool surrounded by myrtle trees. Stalactite vaults known as muqarnas can be found in this complex’s Hall of the Abencerrages ("ah-ben-seh-RAH-ges"), named after an influential family in its city. This complex, which contains a fountain surrounded by twelve statues of lions, is a prime example of Mudejar ("moo-DAY-har") architecture. For 10 points, name this Islamic palace in Granada.

Ignatius's letter to this city makes the otherwise unattested claim that an extremely bright star appeared upon Jesus's death. An address to this city praises their rejecting the Nicolaitans but criticizes them for leaving their "first love". This city's congregation produced the Johannine books and is the first of the seven churches addressed in Revelation. This city's first bishop was Timothy, who was reportedly stoned for preaching against its festival of (*) Diana. Paul's letter to this city tells the readers to put on the Armor of God and infamously instructs wives to submit to their husbands. For three centuries, a cave near this city legendarily protected seven Christians who had fallen asleep inside. For 10 points, name this city in present-day Turkey that hosted the council that rejected Nestorianism.

The solution to this equation can be expressed in terms of an envelope function in the Luttinger-Kohn method. J. H. Shirley showed that expressing this equation in Floquet ("flow-KAY") matrix form and imposing a Fourier basis reproduces tight-binding conditions. The solution of this equation for "x plus a" equals the solution of this equation for (read slowly) x, times a factor of "e to the i-k-a," where k is the crystal momentum vector, according to (*) Bloch's theorem. In the "picture" named for this equation, state vectors evolve in time while operators remain constant. The eigenfunctions of this equation can be computed analytically when the potential is an infinite square well, a system called the "particle in a box". For 10 points, name this differential equation used to describe quantum mechanical systems.

This philosopher remarks that man observes three worlds -- sensual perception, thinking, and the high spiritual -- in a discussion of "experimental intellect" which contrasts "sciences of humans" with those of angels. This man, who is not St. Paul, said "may I be your ransom" during an episode in which he was lowered in a basket from the walls of Damascus. His best-known work includes a "refutation of alchemy" and a discussion of profits often cited as the first formulation of the Laffer Curve. In the (*) introduction to his Book of Lessons, he outlined a cyclical theory that aging civilizations are inevitably conquered by nomadic peoples, such as Berbers, due to the latter's strong social cohesion or asabiya. For 10 points, name this author of the Muqaddimah, a Muslim philosopher of history.
tossups.answer: Ibn Khaldun [or Abū Zayd 'Abd ar-Raḥmān ibn Muḥammad ibn Khaldūn al-Ḥaḍramī]

tossups.question: The last chapter of this novel's first book contains a long riddle on a bronze plate which states "How praiseworthy he / Who shall have persevered even to the end!" 720,831 golden sheep are housed in a hexagonal complex in this novel, whose gate features an inscription prohibiting the entrance of userers, clerks, attorneys, and "vile bigots". That place in this novel is built to celebrate the end of a war over bakers refusing to sell cakes, and inspired the personal motto of (*) Aleister Crowley by having one sole rule: "Do what thou wilt". This novel describes the construction of the utopian Abbey of Thélème ("teh-LEM") after a war against Picrochole ("PEE-kroh-shohl") and the Dipsodes ("DIP-soh-deez") to honor the service of Friar John of the Funnels. For 10 points, name this novel about a pair of giants by François Rabelais ("frahn-SWAH rah-buh-LAY").
tossups.answer: The Life of Gargantua and Pantagruel [or Gargantua et Pantagruel; or La vie de Gargantua et de Pantagruel]

bonuses.leadin: Until 1995, the Otago Daily Times refused to capitalize any instance of this word. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this word, which controversially appeared on the 1996 New Zealand census. This Māori ("mah-oh-ree") word is used to refer to New Zealanders of European descent.

Māori also refer to Europeans as Tangata tiriti, which translates as "people of the Treaty". The "treaty" in question refers to this 1840 one, in which the Māori ceded their land rights to the English crown.
This Dutch Pākehā ("pah-hay-kah") and explorer was one of the first Europeans to make contact with the Māori. This man names the island state of Australia with capital at Hobart.

bonuses.leadin: This symphony's adagio lamentoso finale opens with violins playing a haunting B minor melody in 3/4 ("three-four") time. For 10 points each:
answers: Pathetique Symphony in B Minor, Op. 74 [or Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 6; accept answers indicating the sixth symphony of Pyotr Illyich Tchaikovsky]
parts: What symphony includes a 5/4 "limping waltz" in its second movement? A bassoon plays a solo marked with a dynamic marking of six p in its first movement.

Though Tchaikovsky died nine days after premiering Pathetique, his last composition was an E minor piece in this genre. Tchaikovsky wrote three pieces in this genre for solo keyboard player and orchestra.
A year before dying, Tchaikovsky recommended this Russian for main conductor of Maly Theatre. He is best known for his folksong-laden Symphony No. 1 in G minor.

bonuses.leadin: The title figure of a poem in this collection "has seen the rose bushes / that show their white roses again" prior to visiting his family's house. For 10 points each:
answers: Soledades [or Soledades, Galerias, y otros poemas; or Solitudes, Galleries, and Other Poems]
Generation of '98 [or Generation of 1898; or Generación del 98; or Generación de 1898]
Spanish Golden Age [or Golden Century; or Siglo de Oro]
parts: Name this Antonio Machado collection which contains "The Traveler" and other poems. It shares its title with an earlier collection by Luis de Góngora ("GOHN-goh-rah").
Machado was part of this modernist literary movement whose other members included Miguel de Unamuno. It formed partly in reaction to Spain's defeat by the U.S.
Much of the work of the "Generation of '98" was inspired by the literature from this period of the 16th and 17th centuries, during which Spanish arts and culture flourished.

bonuses.leadin: Some observers dubbed this country's hotly contested March 2020 election a "crude awakening," as it came on the heels of a massive oil discovery. For 10 points each:
answers: Evo Morales [or Juan Evo Morales Ayma]
parts: Name this South American country. The U.S. imposed visa sanctions on this country in July 2020 after David Granger refused to concede to Irfaan Ali in that election.

Pressure from this inter-governmental organization in the Americas was key in getting Granger to concede. This organization, which today mainly focuses on election monitoring, suspended Honduras for two years after the 2009 coup against Manuel Zelaya.
The OAS backed the 2019 ouster of this former Bolivian president on allegations of election fraud, which later independent investigations found to be largely false.

bonuses.leadin: The influx of potassium ions into these cells causes water to rush in, making the cells bulge outward due to turgor pressure. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these cells that regulate the opening and closing of stomata.
In dicots, stomata are abundant on the underside of these structures. Their top sides are typically flat to maximize surface area for photosynthesis.

In developmental plant biology, the upper and undersides of a leaf are also described by these two words, indicating whether they face toward or away from the stem. They're basically botanical analogues of dorsal and ventral.

bonuses.leadin: This man coined such phrases as "welded" and "lohengrinned" for getting married. For 10 points each:
answers: Lindbergh baby kidnapping [accept descriptions involving Charles and Anne Lindbergh's baby being kidnapped]
parts: Name this sensational journalist of the 1930s, who was hired by the New York Daily Mirror to write the first-ever syndicated gossip column. He would often coin catchy nicknames for his enemies.

Winchell and Damon Runyon covered the trial for this crime, which H. L. Mencken referred to as "the biggest story since the Resurrection." A reconstructed ladder helped to prove that Bruno Hauptmann ("brew-no hop-men") committed this crime.
Winchell allegedly negotiated the surrender of mobster Louis Buchalter ("buck-halter") to this person, who was the first director of the FBI.

bonuses.leadin: Traditional examples of these objects are topped by a miniature domed and arched building evoking the Temple and feature the Hebrew letters for mazel tov, as exemplified by one in the Colmar Treasure. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects that must be made of a single piece of unalloyed metal and have a value of at least one prutah.
The groom gives the ring to the bride under this structure central to the wedding, which represents the home that they'll share.
This document is read out loud under the chuppah. This Aramaic-language contract, which is now purely ceremonial and not legally enforceable, states the groom's obligations to the bride.

bonuses.leadin: For an exhibit running from June to October 2016, an artist installed one of these features outside the Palace of Versailles's Grand Canal. For 10 points each:
answers: Christo Vladimirov Javacheff AND Jeanne-Claude Denat de Guillebon [prompt on partial answers]
parts: In 2008, the Danish-Icelandic artist Olafur Eliasson ("oh-lah-foor el-EE-ah-son") recreated what sort of natural feature underneath Brooklyn Bridge?
In 2008, Eliasson ("el-EE-ah-son") surpassed this couple's installations of orange gates in Central Park as the most-expensive public arts project. This couple also wrapped the Reichstag in plastic.

In 2018, Eliasson ("el-EE-ah-son") installed blocks of ice in this city to showcase the negative effects of climate change. Eliasson ("el-EE-ah-son") also created The Weather Project for this city's Tate Modern museum.

bonuses.leadin: The ALPHA experiment was an in-depth study of this substance, which is stored in Penning traps by facilities like CERN. For 10 points each:
answers: equivalence principle [accept the weak equivalence principle or Einstein equivalence principle]
parts: Name this substance, whose constituent particles have the opposite charges of normal particles.

Collisions between protons and antiprotons were used to discover the top quark by this accelerator at Fermilab, the most powerful in the world before the Large Hadron Collider. Its name indicates that it was the first device to reach tera-electron-volt energies.
The GBAR experiment is using antihydrogen to precisely test this statement, which was previously tested in an 1885 experiment involving a torsion balance.

bonuses.leadin: In the original Broadway run of the play she appears in, this character's role was played by Diana Sands. For 10 points each:
answers: To Be Young, Gifted, and Black
parts: Name this character who dreams of being a doctor. To her family's disapproval, she prefers the Nigerian suitor Joseph Asagai over the much older, assimilated George Murchison.
Beneatha Younger is considered a semi-autobiographical portrayal of this author and appears in her play A Raisin in the Sun.

After her death at age 34 from pancreatic cancer, Hansberry's writings were adapted into this play by her ex-husband Robert Nemiroff. This play shares its title with a song that Nina Simone wrote in memory of Hansberry.

bonuses.leadin: This scientist addressed the Great Silence during a lunch break at Los Alamos with the question, "But where is everybody?" For 10 points each:
parts: Name this formulator of a paradox about the contradiction between lack of evidence for extraterrestrial life and the estimated probability of their existence.
This first space probe to leave the Solar System contained a plaque including basic info about Earth and humans that was to serve as a message from mankind to extraterrestrial life.
In 2015, Stephen Hawking announced this most comprehensive SETI effort to date to search a million nearby stars and 100 galaxies for radio and laser transmissions.

bonuses.leadin: In this scene, the narrator is met with laughter after shouting "social responsibility" during a speech. For 10 points each:
answers: "Battle Royal" [accept Chapter 1 of Invisible Man or the first chapter of Invisible Man]
parts: Identify this scene in which the narrator jumps onto an electrified carpet to retrieve gold coins after he and his friends are blindfolded. You may also give the chapter number and the novel which it is found in.
The "Battle Royal" scene opens this African-American author's novel Invisible Man.

Before the "Battle Royal," the unnamed narrator observes a dancing woman with one of these objects tattooed on her belly. In a discussion about choosing one for The Brotherhood, Brother Westrum says "everybody wants" one of these objects.

bonuses.leadin: A central concept of this text is interpenetration, illustrated by Indra's net; a namesake sect also used the metaphor of a candle surrounded by mirrors. For 10 points each:
answers: Flower Garland Sutra [or Flower Ornament Sutra; or Flower Adornment Sutra; or Avatamsaka Sutra; or Huayan Jing; or Kegon Kyou; or Hwaeom Gyeong; or Hoa Nghiêm Kinh; or Mahavaipulya Buddhavatamsaka Sutra; or Dafangguang Fohuayan Jing; or Daihoukou Butsukegon Kyou; or Daebanggwang Bulhwaeom Gyeong; or Dai Phuong Quang Phât Hoa Nghiêm Kinh]
emptiness [or empty; or voidness; or hollowness; accept nothingness; or kong; or kuu; or gong; or không]
Zen [or Chan; or Seon; or Thiên]
parts: Name this long sutra that describes the fractal view of the universe seen by the Buddhas, who manifest in every atom. Its title object represents the glory of the Buddhas' understanding of the true nature of reality.

The Buddhas' view of the universe comes from knowing that all phenomena have this property that causes them to infinitely interpenetrate. The Heart Sutra equates form and this property, which in Sanskrit is called shunyata ("SHOON-yuh-tah").
The Flower Garland School's doctrines heavily influenced the development of this other Mahayana school focused on meditation and emptiness.

bonuses.leadin: This word precedes Shoki in the title of a text which addressed historical errors with the Kojiki. For 10 points each:
answers: Prince Shotoku [or Prince Umayado; or Prince Kamitsumiya]
parts: Give this Japanese word which became Japan's official name late in the 7th century. It loosely translates as "sun origin," giving rise to the epithet "Land of the Rising Sun".
In correspondence with Emperor Yang of Sui, this prince encouraged him to call Japan by Nihon. Through the Seventeen-Article Constitution, he promoted Buddhism as Japan's state religion.
Worship of Prince Shotoku peaked with the creation of the Shoko mandara during this period, which began after the defeat of the Taira clan at the Battle of Dan-no-ura.

bonuses.leadin: In April 2020, Felix Klein started a furor in Germany by attempting to bar this scholar from giving a speech because he "relativized the Holocaust". For 10 points each:
answers: The Wretched of the Earth [or Les Damnés de la Terre]
parts: Name this Cameroonian author of On the Postcolony, who coined the term "necropolitics" to describe the use of power to dictate whether people live or die.
Mbembe's "necropolitics" is a development of this French philosopher's concepts of "biopolitics" and "biopower," which are defined in his book The History of Sexuality.
Mbembe's work also draws on this 1961 book by Frantz Fanon, which argues that revolutionary colonial subjects exemplify the lumpenproletariat of Marxist theory.

bonuses.leadin: A namesake theorem equates the integral of a meromorphic function around a loop to 2 pi i times the sum of this value at all poles inside. For 10 points each:
answers: (Julius Wilhelm) Richard Dedekind [accept Dedekind zeta functions or Dedekind eta function]
prime [accept word forms like primality or primes; accept prime ideals, prime numbers, or prime factorization]
parts: Name the coefficient of the -1 term in a meromorphic function's Laurent series.

The class number formula gives in arithmetic (“arithMETic”) terms the residue at 1 of this man's zeta functions, which generalize Riemann's to number fields. His zeta function is a weight 1/2 modular form whose 24th power times a constant is the modular discriminant.
Dedekind zeta functions have an Euler product over ideals with this property. Each of the integers has a unique "factorization" into a product of these numbers.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about health care in the Middle Ages:
answers: Benedictines [or Order of Saint Benedict; or O.S.B.]
Innocent III [or Lotario dei Conti di Segni; or Lothar of Segni; prompt on Innocent]
Paracelsus [or Philippus Aureolus Theophrastus Bombastus von Hohenheim]
parts: Perhaps the biggest provider of health care in the Middle Ages was this monastic order, founded by a saint from Nursia. They are known for wearing black habits.

The Hospital of the Holy Spirit, Europe's oldest hospital, was founded with efforts from this pope. He decreed a crusade that was assisted by Enrico Dandolo in his bull Post miserabile ("mee-seh-RAH-bee-lay").

Medicine improved with this Swiss scientist's discovery of laudanum, which was used as an anesthetic until the 19th century. He also published one of the earliest tracts on surgery, The Great Surgery Book.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name these concepts from the volume Capitalism and Schizophrenia by Gilles Deleuze ("zheel deh-LUHZ") and Félix Guattari ("feh-leeks gwuh-tah-REE"):
answers: territories [accept territorialization or reterritorialization or deterritorialization; accept the map is not the territory]
parts: The first of the volume's two books is titled for, and offers a critique of, the Freudian "complex" named for this man who had sex with his mother Jocasta.

The volume uses a verb referring to these places to describe the process in which capitalism separates material flows from their origins. An oft-cited quote claims "the map" is not one of these places.
The volume borrows this term from botany to describe deterritorialized networks with no beginning or end, and structures its book A Thousand Plateaus as one of them.

bonuses.leadin: Two major styles of this art form are the angular, older Kufic style and the smaller, rounded Naskh style. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this form of intricate writing. Arabic examples are done on a variety of mediums using a dried reed pen, while Chinese examples typically use a brush.
In Turkish mosques, many of these spaces - which are named for their half-moon shape and are often found above archways - contain calligraphic verses from the Qur'an.
Many lunettes were done in this Turkish style of tiling that combined Ottoman and Chinese patterns. This style, named for a town in western Anatolia, was often used in the buildings of Mimar Sinan.

bonuses.leadin: W. S. di Piero produced the first full English translation of this author's aphorisms, the Pensieri ("pen-see-AIR-ee"). For 10 points each:
answers: shipwrecks [or shipwrecking; accept naufragar or naufragio or naufrage; accept answers which refer to being shipwrecked; prompt on wrecking or drowning or deaths]
parts: Name this Italian Romantic poet of "To Silvia" who wrote "This solitary hill has always been dear to me" to begin the poem "The Infinite".
"The Infinite" is one of these fourteen-line poems, which were pioneered by the earlier Italian author Petrarch.

The speaker of "The Infinite" concludes by saying that one of these events would be "sweet to me". Stéphane Mallarmé's poem "A Throw of the Dice Will Never Abolish Chance" begins by pondering the "eternal circumstance" of the aftermath of these events.
